description: From Middle English lather, from Old English lēaþor (“a kind of niter used for soap, soda”), from Proto-Germanic *lauþrą (“that which is used for washing, soap”), from Proto-Indo-European *lówh₃trom (“that which is used for washing”), from *lewh₃-, *lowh₃- (“to wash, bathe”). Cognate with Swedish lödder (“lather, foam, froth, soap”), Icelandic löður (“foam, froth, a kind of niter used for soap”), Old Irish lóathar (“wash-basin”), Ancient Greek λουτρόν (loutrón, “a bath, wash-room”), Latin lavō (“I wash”), Albanian laj (“I wash”), Ancient Greek λούω (loúō). More at lye.

entries.meaning: (countable, uncountable) The foam made by rapidly stirring soap and water.
(countable, uncountable) Foam from profuse sweating, as of a horse.

description: From Middle English *lethren, from Old English lēþrian, lȳþrian, *līeþrian (“to anoint, smear, lather”), from Old English lēaþor (“a kind of niter used for soap, soda”). See above.

verbs.description: lather (third-person singular simple present lathers, present participle lathering, simple past and past participle lathered)

examples: The young woman lathered her breasts with lavender-scented soap.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To form lather or froth, as a horse does when profusely sweating.
